content.webTitle: 44 nations to contest Winter Paralympics starting on Friday | Sochi 2014

fields.headline: Sochi 2014: 44 nations set to contest Winter Paralympics starting on Friday
fields.bodyText: THE GAMES Sochi returns to centre stage when the 11th Winter Paralympics begin with Friday's opening ceremony. Competition takes place over nine days in the same venues as the Winter Olympics. The Games feature around 700 competitors from 44 nations, including newcomers Brazil, Turkey and Uzbekistan, though South Africa's decision not to send anyone means no African country will be represented. THE FLAME The Sochi Paralympic flame will be formed at a Flame Uniting Ceremony on Wednesday. Flames from 46 different Russian cities, plus a new Heritage Flame lit in Stoke Mandeville, Aylesbury, on Saturday night, will come together to form the Paralympic flame for the final days of the relay. Saturday night's event was part of a new tradition recognising Stoke Mandeville as the birthplace of the Paralympic movement in 1948. THE SPORTS Alpine skiing: Includes downhill, super-G, slalom and super-combined disciplines in sitting, standing and visually impaired skiing (athletes ski with a guide in front of them). Biathlon: Athletes ski three 2.5km legs (7.5km in total) and fire at five targets (located 10m from the shooter) between each leg using air guns mounted on stands. Sitting, standing and visually impaired categories. Cross-country skiing: Individual or Team, Classical or Freestyle events ranging between 2.5km and 20km. Skiers with visual impairments compete with a guide, while athletes with a physical impairment compete using either a sit-ski or standing using one or two skis and/or poles. Ice sledge hockey: A full-contact, high-speed game that has been called wheelchair rugby on ice. Wheelchair curling: No sweeping – it's all about the delivery from hand or stick. THE BRITISH TEAM There are 15 ParalympicsGB athletes – five for Wheelchair Curling and 10 for alpine skiing (seven skiers and three guides) – aiming to win Britain's first ever Winter Paralympic gold. The best to date is a silver in curling at Turin 2006. Among the skiers look out for 15-year-old Millie Knight, Britain's youngest ever Winter Paralympian; Kelly Gallagher (left) the first Winter Paralympian from Northern Ireland and Mick Brennan, who has come through the military Battle Back programme, with support from Help for Heroes. Gallagher and her guide, Charlotte Evans; Jade Etherington and guide Caroline Powell and sit-skier Anna Turney have all won World medals since the start of 2014, while the (mixed gender) wheelchair curling team includes the only female skip at international level in Aileen Neilson, (left) and one athlete who was part of the Turin silver medal-winning side (Angie Malone). The curlers won silver at the 2011 World Championships and came 6th at the 2013 World Championships. THE TV COVERAGE Channel 4, following on from its Bafta award-winning coverage of London 2012, is showing 50 hours live with its sister, More 4, plus two special editions of the comedy show The Last Leg. The LEXI decoder returns, explaining the different classifications involved. The first action on Channel 4 is the opening ceremony at 3.30pm on Friday, presented by Jon Snow.
